PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, do you stand by your statements that there is no windfall gain arising from Telstra's record profit of $2.3 billion for 1995-96 and that suggestions that part of that profit should be used for such purposes as funding the Natural Heritage Trust are `spurious economics`?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —What is required here is a careful examination of the figures. For example—
—Is this what you said to Tim Fischer, Richard?

—Do you want the answer or not? The operating profit after tax and minority interest was $2.3 billion in 1996. In June 1995, that figure was $1.755 billion. If you look at the dividend figure of $1.368 billion, you find that is only about $74 million more than the implicit figure which we had budgeted for. In other words, there is a very minor increase.
—What was the dividend last year compared with this year?

—Look, I know it is a bit simplistic and your approach does not readily lend itself to this sort of analysis, but there are two elements: one is the dividend payment and the other is the increase in corporate taxation. Senator Kernot was arguing that the increase in corporate tax was very significant because she said it was something like 76 per cent compared with 7.9 per cent last year. The fact is that that 7.9 per cent did not relate to Telstra. That is an overall increase in the level of corporate taxation and that disguises a multitude of ups and downs, pluses and minuses. It certainly does not tell you anything about the level of increase in Telstra's corporate taxation contributions last year, nor does it tell you what its increase might be this year.
—So do you stand by your statement?

—I am in the process of explaining it to you. It is also very important to recognise that, because you are talking about the aggregate of contributions to revenue, there is no such thing as a windfall in this situation any more than there might be if BHP suddenly had a record result and increased funds were available. You cannot simply say, `Well, that means we got more than we expected; we can therefore spend that money.' You have to balance this out. You have to look at all the pluses and minuses, as I said in my release yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I cannot hear but I presume we will have this debate in the MPI. To the extent that the increase is due to an increase in its market share, then that is at the expense of its competitors. You may well argue that that means that their contribution to corporate taxes would be commensurately less. So there is no basis for saying that a one-off increase in the level of corporate taxation constitutes a windfall gain in this area any more than it does anywhere else.

ANSWER.PARA: The same applies to the dividend payment. The dividend payment is substantially taken into account in the budget projections. In fact, we have already received 50 per cent of that figure announced last Friday. So that has already been factored in and received. The next amount will not be payable until December this year and that will then take account of the lag effect. That will be part of what was announced on Friday as well.

You have to remember that about 90 per cent of the total increase in operating profit is due to an increase in revenue—about $1.1 billion—and efficiencies constitute less than 10 per cent. On that basis, you cannot possibly assume that this is anything other than a snapshot of the performance of one corporation at a particular point in time. It tells you nothing about next year and how it will perform then.

TALK.START.PARA: —So how does this compare with the price for the proposed sale?

—I have made it clear to you: the dividend was broadly anticipated in budget statement No. 4. The level of corporate taxes is quite a spurious figure because it is not related to Telstra's level of increase; it is related to the overall level of corporate tax payable in the last financial year. That is no more a windfall gain than any increased performance by any other company. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that straightforward explanation of how he stood by his statements that to use part of the profit of Telstra for a purpose such as funding the Natural Heritage Trust was spurious economics. Given that you have made that statement, Senator Alston, will you now repudiate the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, and his statement that was reported on page 1 of the Australian this morning that Telstra has delivered a couple of hundred million extra to the budget which could be spent on other policies? Who is right, Minister—you or Mr Fischer?

—I am not sure how that constitutes a supplementary question, because it has nothing to do with whether I stood by my statement that there were no windfall gains—and I clearly do. I have made it very clear to you that I am not in the business of offering gratuitous advice to anyone except your good selves, and I will do that as often as the occasion requires it. The fact is you want to know as a matter of public policy—
—What do you know?

—I know you do not want to know. What I am being asked is whether there is a windfall profit there that would somehow be available for others to spend on other purposes. Well, there is no magic pudding.
—The Deputy Prime Minister thinks there is.

—I do not know whether you have even the vaguest idea of how these things are calculated. I think it all just washed over you. I explained to you that there are two critical elements: the dividend payment and the increase in corporate taxes. I have explained why both of those do not constitute a windfall gain; yet you seem totally oblivious to the economics of the argument. I can understand why you would take that approach. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I draw the minister's attention to yet another irresponsible media release made last week by Senator Sherry alleging that the government's superannuation policies have caused uncertainty within the industry and the broader community. Can the minister advise the Senate on the impact of these government policies and, in particular, the government's commitment to choice in superannuation—something that Labor did not recognise as a priority during its failed 13 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for his question. It gives me another opportunity to point out to the Senate—with regret, I must say—how much Senator Sherry has become the Labor Party spokesman for superannuation scaremongering. He has been at it for weeks and weeks now. In the most disgraceful way, he has deliberately put fear into the hearts of thousands of people approaching retirement. He did it again when he made a statement on Friday in relation to the opt‐out provisions that the government has announced for very low income earners, so far as the superannuation guarantee arrangements are concerned, whereby, under the budget announcement that the government has made, someone earning between $450 and $900 a month will be able to opt out of the superannuation guarantee arrangements and instead receive, in lieu, wages to the equivalent amount.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that our policy is based on a very simple concept that Labor seems to have no comprehension of at all—and that is the concept called choice. We believe that Australians are intelligent enough to think for themselves and have the basic fundamental right to be able to make a choice in areas such as this. True to form, Senator Sherry seems to take no regard of this and seems to have no comprehension at all of this fundamental thing.

If a person is receiving less than $900 a month and if they wish to have additional wage or salary to pay their rent or to meet essential living expenses, that will be their choice. Labor says that they should not have that choice, despite the fact that they may be coming from a situation where they are battling to make ends meet, where every dollar might help them to make ends meet. Labor says, `No, we are not going to let you do that.' That applies to casual workers, to people who are in and out of the work force—

TALK.START.PARA: —Women on low pay.

—And, as Senator Newman says, to women on low pay or part-time arrangements. `No choice,' says the Labor Party. We believe there should be choice and that people should be free to negotiate with their employer to have the additional income instead of superannuation.

ANSWER.PARA: We acknowledge—and we have acknowledged in the budget papers—that up to 80 per cent of people who qualify for opting out may in fact choose to do so. But that is a matter for their own intelligent choice. Under the government's policy, people will continue to benefit from the superannuation guarantee when their income moves above $900 a month, and if they exercise a choice and they think it is in their best interest, if their income is less than $900 a month, to stay in the superannuation guarantee arrangements, then they will do so.

I would ask Senator Sherry: why is he so against letting Australian people make up their minds in this respect? Why is he so determined not to allow people choice? It is the old approach of Labor that the state knows better than the individual what is in the individual's best interest. That is one of the fundamental differences between this side of politics and your side of politics. That is one of the fundamental reasons why you were so comprehensively thrown out of office on 2 March. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response, which clearly indicates the benefits of the government's choice model for superannuation over Labor's patronising big brother approach. Would the minister care to comment on the statement by Senator Sherry that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the ALP will be seeking to reinstate stability, certainty and confidence in superannuation by referring all super issues to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. In accordance with previous rulings you have made, I ask you whether the supplementary question, as asked by Senator Chapman, asking that the minister comment on statements of Senator Sherry—
—Or the ALP.
—Or the ALP—whether that is in order. Clearly, in terms of previous rulings you have made, that is out of order.

—Madam President, on the point of order: in my submission, it is relevant for the government to be asked whether or not a policy position that it takes is one that is shared by the other side of politics and how the government itself would respond to proposals put by the other side of politics. It is perfectly proper for a minister to comment on statements that Senator Sherry might have made in the context of how that would affect the government's approach to policy matters.

—The question was not asked quite in that form. The only answer that Senator Short could give to it would relate to his own portfolio and the government's response to it, but not otherwise on opposition policy.

—I accept that ruling because the misinformation that is being spread by the opposition on this matter goes to the heart of the government's own policies on superannuation. Indeed, it would be funny, if it was not so serious, to hear Senator Sherry's empty words about the opposition reinstating stability, certainty and confidence to superannuation when his own continued campaign of scaremongering is doing irreparable damage to community confidence in superannuation.

—Madam President, I rise on the point of order that Senator Short, in his answer to the typewritten supplementary question asked by Senator Chapman, has in fact flouted your ruling. He is not now commenting on matters relating to his own portfolio; he is addressing extraneous matters, including making an attempt to place words in Senator Sherry's mouth. That is clearly contrary to the ruling you have just made. I would ask you to rule him out of order and sit him down.
—The minister must confine his answer to matters within his own portfolio and government policy.

—Thank you, Madam President. As a result of Senator's Sherry's deliberate misinformation campaign on this basis, he is undermining the confidence of the community, particularly that of low income earners, in their ability to exercise choice in their own interests when it comes to the matter of the superannuation policies and proposals by the government in relation to low income earners. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications and the Arts. Are you aware that Mr Blount, the Chief Executive Officer of Telstra, on radio last Friday in answering a question about Telstra moving jobs offshore to the Philippines said:

QUESTION.PARA: Well, look, if it is cheaper we will do it—and if it's best practice.

Will you be taking any action as the minister responsible for Telstra to keep Telstra jobs in Australia? And will you rein in Telstra's mania for downsizing that will see 22,000 Telstra jobs disappear over the next three years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see those reported remarks of Mr Blount, but I did have a discussion with Mr Blount late last week, in which I canvassed with him the one line that was contained in the Senate report that suggested that perhaps operator assisted service jobs might be taken offshore—indeed, I think, to the Philippines. The answer I got was, firstly, that Mr Blount had not been involved in any such discussions and, secondly, that he was not interested in proposals that, on the face of it, did not seem to offer any significant benefits in terms of productivity and certainly did not seem to be in Telstra's best interests if it was concerned to retain an image of Australian‐ness.

ANSWER.PARA: What was said at the press conference in the context of announcing the record profit result was that over the next two years there would be additional reductions in employment levels. There is nothing surprising about that. Indeed, as we know, between 1991 and 1994 Telstra reduced its work force by about the same level as we are now talking about—in other words, about 25,000 jobs. The unions themselves have conceded on a number of occasions that technology gains and productivity improvements will inevitably result in job losses—they have factored that into the equation. Both Ian McLean and Colin Cooper have said that—and both are from the CEPU.

It is quite clear that there is also a need to address efficiency problems and, as I have indicated in relation to the announced figure the other day, only a very small proportion of that could be attributed to any gains in efficiency. And unless you get efficiencies in place, Senator Childs, through you Madam President, you will not be able to deliver the world‐class service that we all want; you will not be able to get lower prices and better quality of service; you will not be able to get their access lines per employee up above 135 to the 200‐plus that you get in New Zealand and even close to 300 for the RBOC.

In other words, it is very important that Telstra is allowed to make commercial decisions. That is what the 1991 act is all about. It is not a matter of interfering and giving instructions; it is a matter of Telstra exercising its own sensitivity on these issues. Quite clearly, Telstra will be cognisant of the need to ensure that it is not simply reducing employment levels by head count and that it is doing it only in areas where it will contribute to the efficiency of the system and enable it to compete much more effectively after 1 July next year.

These are all very important issues because telecommunications costs are the second‐ largest cost input for most businesses after wages and salaries and, unless you have an efficient Telstra, unless it is able to compete against newcomers into the game, it will be very much handicapped. You put management in positions to make those hard decisions. No‐one gets any joy out of reducing labour in whatever sector it might be, but if there is one industry in which you would like to be if your job were at risk, it would be in a sector where the growth rate is about 18 per cent. The telecommunications industry is growing at that level and, as Ian McLean himself said, if jobs go from Telstra, they are likely to go to the private sector—in other words, you can confidently expect that there will be a huge demand for jobs from the telecommunications industry. That was said by SPAN and ATUG to the Senate committee. I am sorry that you chose to ignore that because it is very important evidence. To the extent that people are unable to be employed by Telstra, their prospects of being employed elsewhere are very good. And that is one of the great virtues of this industry and why you want to have as much efficiency as possible. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Do you accept that even a minister who, unlike you, has the best interests of Australians at heart, would be unable to prevent either job losses or jobs going offshore once Telstra is privatised?
—As has been said many times by Mr Blount and others, the current efficiency drives and changes in Telstra are unrelated to privatisation.
—Ah, ah! Come on.

—You don't want to believe it. I know you don't. But everyone else, I think, understands. Were they driven by privatisation between 1991 and 1994? They may have been if you accept the proposition that Kim Beazley was out there promising privately that Telstra might be privatised, but that is not what anyone else says. What happened at that time was that they were reducing jobs in line with the need to create greater efficiencies and in order to make Telstra more competitive. The same thing is happening again now and therefore it is criti cally important to look at whether you have a Telstra that is in world shape—
—Answer the question.

—That is the answer to the question. I know you do not want to know about it but the fact is that those changes are not privatisation driven. Mr Blount has said it repeatedly, and that is the case. I am sure it will continue to be the approach adopted. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Alston in his capacity as Minister for Communications and the Arts. I ask the minister: is it the government's intention to review the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989? While you are answering that, would you please also explain to honourable senators, particularly to our parliamentary colleagues on the other side, how this compares with Labor's alternative approach?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Back on 15 November 1993, the then minister for communications, David Beddall, announced that Labor had agreed to proposals for a sensible, managed approach to the introduction of further competition. He went on to say that the review would be conducted in 1996‐97, with terms of reference consistent with the findings of the national competition policy review. He also said that it was the government's view that a public monopoly must justify the continuation of its monopoly position. Indeed, we went to the election matching Labor's promise. The Treasurer, on 28 June, announced that a review of Australia Post would commence in 1996‐97.

ANSWER.PARA: It is against that background that I was very interested to see the shadow minister for industry and regional Australia, Simon Crean, interviewed on the Sunday program. He was asked about these issues and he gave a constructive and measured approach. He said:

Well, I think it depends on circumstances in which you let the competition come in. If you retain—if you have a community service obligation, it is possible to open up, I think, more to private competition as long as you're guaranteeing the service.
Laurie Oakes:
So would Labor support that?
Simon Crean:
What Labor would support is initiatives if they are to improve efficiency, as long as you guarantee the service to the remote and regional areas of this country.

That is a perfectly unexceptionable statement. It is very much in line with our concerns. The basis on which we will be conducting that review is to ensure that all Australians are provided with better and more efficient postal services. We were the only party that went to the election promising to improve postal services to regional and rural Australia. Indeed, we are in the process of delivering on those promises.

What is appalling is that three days later Mr Crean apparently got rolled by Senator Schacht, who then proceeded to put out a press release saying that the Opposition had declared it was not interested in supporting any changes to the present operating rules and regulations of Australia Post. He said:
Unlike many other countries in the world, Australia Post pays a dividend to the Australian government.

I do not know whether he meant that other countries in the world pay dividends to the Australian government or whether Australia Post pays dividends to other countries in the world. Putting aside the tortuous grammar of the whole release, it is clear from this that Senator Schacht simply is not interested in good public policy. The opposition, presumably, has reneged on that longstanding commitment.

None of that is surprising because if you had read the Australian of 29 June you would have seen an interview called `Ordinary people'. I have to say that it was about very ordinary people—about Labor people who were suffering mightily from not being able to rule as they had presumed they were born to do. On that occasion, Senator Schacht said:
Some of us were never overly sucked in by the Cabinet process. We always felt there was too much time debating the minutiae of administration and not enough pure politics.

Overlooking for a moment the fact that he was never in cabinet so he was not in there debating anything, what that tells you is that he is not interested in any shape or form about improving the lot of people in rural and remote areas and about benefiting consumers. He is simply interested in a very tawdry and tacky game of running scare campaigns, playing politics, not looking at the detail of issues, rolling ministers, like Mr Crean, and shadow ministers when they have the temerity to suggest that there might be a constructive approach based on their own announcement three years earlier.

We have here a morally and policy bankrupt opposition who no longer have the slightest interest in improving the welfare of ordinary Australians or postal users. The senator is someone who is here simply earning a living playing the game of politics. That is a very sad state of affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston—Mr Howard's doormat. Minister, do you agree with Mr Donald McDonald, the chairman of the ABC, that imposing ABC cuts before the Mansfield review had even commenced was putting the cart before the horse? Do you agree with Mr McDonald's claim that the ABC must provide a comprehensive service catering for all Australian needs and tastes rather than a service which simply complements what others do?
—Senator Schacht, quick off the mark as usual—I think this is about five or six days old but, nonetheless—
—So what?

—Well, I suppose it took him three years to roll his own party in relation to issues of policy in Australia Post. It is important to understand in this whole debate that it was very important in establishing the Mansfield review that we should indicate funding levels at this stage so that the ABC would have certainty of funding and the time to review its operations and range of activities in line with the new funding level. The proposed Mansfield review will be a major input into determining the range of activities.

BREAK.PARA: It is quite clear that if Senator Schacht has the wit or the will to put a few thoughts on paper—I suppose the time has expired; he had every chance but I bet he did not take it—he could have made a submission—

TALK.START.PARA: —When did submissions close?
—They closed some weeks ago. It may even be possible that you could get leave. But the important thing is that we should all await the outcome of the Mansfield review.

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of important issues, particularly whether services to regional and rural Australia ought to be properly protected in the charter, and whether news and current affairs should be properly catered for in the charter. Once again, it is a very sad state of affairs when you can draw attention to existing inadequacies in the charter and you find the sort of knee‐jerk, pavlovian response that says, `We're not interested in any change to the charter'—in other words, once again playing pure politics.

If you want to argue these issues—I think I have already demonstrated to the Senate your contribution on the ABC, which basically consisted of a couple of desultory press releases taking the union line, wanting to make sure that management got thrashed rather than the workers—that is not what I call sensible policy debate.

Issues such as the ones you raised about comprehensiveness or complementarity are the sorts of issues that will be addressed at the Mansfield inquiry. I trust you will have a constructive approach when you get that report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you may be interested to know that I have indicated to Mr Mansfield that I will be putting a submission in.
—That you will be!

—Yes, and I will have discussions on this. You might be interested to know that 11,000 submissions were received—you would not have known that—and it took six days for the fax machine to be cleared in Mr Mansfield's office. So con cerned are the Australian public to preserve the ABC. Do you agree with Mr McDonald's call for public hearings, as part of the Mansfield inquiry process, or do you think that there should be no hearings and no chance for the public to further expand on their views about the future of the ABC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —What a devastating self‐indictment. We have just been told that 11,000 Australians managed to get their submissions in on time yet the shadow minister, the bloke who ought to be right on top of the field, ought to have the issues at his fingertips, ought to have had his press release drafted the day after that announcement, is still weeks later wondering what he could possibly say to Mr Mansfield to cover up his own inadequacies. That really is a very sad state of affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that Mr Mansfield will demonstrate the sort of compassion that you do not deserve and will give you leave to table your submission out of time. You have the resources of the union movement. You have thousands of rolled gold supporters who would stop at nothing to provide funding. All you had to do was ask. We could have helped you. I could have given you some background material. There are plenty of people here who could have helped you. Senator Ray no doubt could have helped you. I know you are a slow learner, but I did not realise that you were such a slow writer. Certainly, if you have anything useful to contribute, I am sure that you will put it to Mr Mansfield eventually. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't answer the question.
—I forgot.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. You have relied on three main arguments for why you should be allowed to sell Telstra. The first thing you have said is that it will increase public savings. Is it not true that this has been shot down by your own National Commission of Audit? They have rejected the cash flow based accounting method used by the government. Secondly, you said that it will benefit consumers. Is it not true that this has fallen to the arguments implicit in your own regulation whereby you say that we have to have regulation to safeguard consumer interests? The main argument you have relied on is efficiency. Is it not true that this has been shot down by Telstra itself which has reduced its costs per line to eight per cent below the world average and they are falling? With the last fig leaf of your argument blown away, is it not true that all you are left with is the naked, blinkered ideology: we should do it because everybody is doing it, no matter what is best for Australia? Is it not true that privatisation serves both as the means and the end to coalition policy? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have now is a dry run of the urgency motion. I have no doubt that we will canvass all of these issues in much greater detail at that time. It is not correct to say that there are only three reasons we want to go down the privatisation path. Frank Blount gave five major reasons for this. One which I can remind you about is the inherent conflict of interest in the government wanting to maximise revenue by way of dividends. You will remember what Paul Keating did when he was short of a quid. Basically, he went to them and demanded another $400 million or $600 million to plug his budget bottom line. It had nothing to do with benefiting consumers. You need to have that arms length arrangement.

ANSWER.PARA: I see what Senator Kernot is doing. She really just wants an advanced run of the arguments so that they can be dealt with later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary yet.

—That is okay. I was simply suggesting that that might have been a useful approach. It is also important that you have a share price signal; in other words, so you can assess on a daily basis whether it is performing.

ANSWER.PARA: The important thing to remember with regard to the figure announced on Friday is that annual revenue has increased by 8.2 per cent and expenses grew by eight per cent. That is the first time in the last couple of years that revenue has actually stayed ahead of the increase in expenses. There is still a very long way to go. There is no reason why you ought to assume that somehow Telstra is going to get much closer to world's best practice except over a very long period and only with the sort of intervention that no doubt Labor would regard as perfectly appropriate. That is not why the rest of the world has gone down the privatisation path. They have done it because they see it as—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Albania again.
—I have explained to you that all of those countries see very real benefits in having businesses run as commercial operations.
—For whom?

—For the benefit of all. If you get efficiencies in the system then you have a capacity to deliver lower prices, better quality of services and increase the choice of products—all of those things that result from a lower cost structure. If your cost structure is too high your capacity to undercut your competitors is reduced and you end up with either a cosy duopoly or simply not a real contest. If you do have those efficiencies and you do have a private sector component you can, at the same time, overlay the rules and regulations that are important to ensure cross‐subsidies, price caps, untimed local calls and consumer, customer guarantees. All of these things operate in countries like America which has never had any public ownership of telecommunications carriers. The system works perfectly well.
—Oh, rubbish! Rubbish!

—I have just said to you that the greatest single measure of efficiency is access lines per employee. In the United States, the average for the RBOC is in excess of 300 and in Australia it is 135. In other words, our cost structures are very much out of kilter with the rest of the world. What happens in those countries is that they achieve a perfectly proper balance between imposing, by way of law, certain obligations on otherwise private operators. The mix works very satisfactorily because the commercial incentives are there. You do not simply have to take your orders from the unions or the Labor Party, you make decisions on the basis of commercial efficiency and, at the same time, you comply with the government requirements whether for untimed local calls or any other social obligation. That way you end up with a very efficient system. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it that in not addressing public savings and regulations providing benefits to consumers you concede those arguments? On the matter of efficiency, you rely all the time on world's best practice. Is it not true that that is an artificial construct, but world average is what we should be dealing with—the here and now? What do you say to Alan Kohler when he reported Telstra managers as saying that cutting costs to world's best practice would damage the organisation and that in chasing world's best practice you are chasing an unachievable goal of telecommunications perfection? It is good to have them there as an ideal, but there is nothing wrong with the measure of efficiency contained in world's average prices where we are doing very well.
—I am not surprised that whoever said that was not prepared to put his name to it in public.
—He did!

—Alan Kohler was quoting an unnamed senior Telstra manager. Right? So just listen. The important thing is that that is a recipe for mediocrity. I am surprised that you would not at least acknowledge that you ought to move to world's best practice over time. That is a very desirable goal. No‐one is suggesting you do it overnight and yet you could in fact find those sorts of disruptions if you were to try to impose it immediately. If you do not at least aspire to it, if you do not start to move in the right direction, then you will always have a second‐class system.
—That is what you measure on the way through.

—I have been to addresses made by Mr Blount to the work force and he tells them that they are 30 per cent off the pace by world standards. On savings, reducing the level of public debt is very important. That is a separate argument which I am happy to address a little later. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs representing the Attorney‐General. Is it not a fact that the South Australian Attorney‐General, Mr Griffin, has publicly stated:

QUESTION.PARA: If the Commonwealth retreats from its (legal aid) obligations to the people for whom it has traditionally been responsible, the State Government is unlikely to be in a position where it can step in and fund the shortfall.

I also note that similar comments have been made by nearly all of Australia's state and territory attorneys‐general. What are the implications for Australia's justice and legal aid systems, given that the states are either unable or unwilling to make up the shortfall in legal aid funding caused by your government's already announced decision to limit its traditional areas of responsibility in legal aid funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I am not aware of what comments the South Australian Attorney‐General may have made with respect to this matter. Furthermore, I am not aware of whether the Commonwealth Attorney‐General is aware of the remarks that the South Australian Attorney‐General has made. But I undertake to chase up those remarks. You might be kind enough to give me a reference to them. I will forward them to the Attorney‐General and get a response for you.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. As you are aware, minister, today is World Ozone Day. What action is Australia taking to reduce emissions of ozone depleting chemicals which are a danger to our environment and our health? How does this fit with the government's commitment to the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator. I think all senators know her particular interest in health matters. Today is World Ozone Day. We recognise, really, one of the extraordinary achievements of the international community and that is efforts to stabilise ozone levels in the upper atmosphere and, ultimately, towards the year 2040 to reduce them. Ozone depletion, of course, leads to increased UV radiation which is in fact damaging to both the environment and to health.

PARA.BREAK: In gives me the opportunity to put on the record the commitment of this new Australian government to continue with the domestic response and domestic control programs that are administered by my department and also to continue and to accelerate our programs of assistance towards developing neighbours in order that they might also substantially contribute to the ultimate benefits that would flow from the whole of the international community cooperating under this convention. In parti cular, I refer to programs that we have in place with Kiribati, the Solomon Islands and with Vanuatu. It also gives me the opportunity to record that the achievements so far are not only achievements by government but, as a result of cooperation between government, by the community and industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I particularly wanted to mention today the contributions made by the administrators of our sporting venues. In a release I put out earlier this morning, I mentioned the fact that the Olympic Stadium at Homebush is to include in its state‐of‐the‐art design the use of passive ventilation to minimise the need for airconditioning. As with the Olympic Aquatic Centre, maximum use will be made of natural cooling and ventilation, and I think that that is a good example to other developers.

Secondly, the MCG has just completed a program to eliminate CFC gas in all airconditioning and 70 major refrigeration units. Additionally, the MCG no longer uses foam cups made with CFCs. And the Sydney Cricket Ground has completed the replacement of CFC chemicals in all airconditioning plant and is in the process of replacing the chemicals in its smaller domestic refrigerators. So our industry is in fact showing a good example.

Lastly, it must be remembered that, although the levels of UV radiation may have stabilised, they are still dangerously high. As we move into summer, it is important that all Australians realise that stabilisation is not good enough and that the UV levels are still extremely level. The warning then is to all Australians during summer to cover up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from debating the detail of the profit levels—which is something that my colleague started to do, and no doubt it is a debate that is going to continue—I think that the honourable senator is really double counting because any profits that are made by Telstra are fed into recurrent expenditure, which of course was running, under the previous government, at a deficit level of approximately $10 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. You would have seen in today's Australian Financial Review a report by two ANU academics identifying that Australia's share of the east Asian market has fallen from about 4.05 per cent of imports in 1985 to 2.89 per cent of imports in 1993, equating to about $12 billion worth of export earnings for Australia forgone. Is the minister aware that the economists nominate lack of competitiveness of Australia's exports as one of the major reasons for this fall? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ian Macdonald for his question. Senator Macdonald, I can recall, was one of those who for years was telling Labor, when they were in government, that they had failed to appreciate some essential facts—that is, that our export economy is linked within the efficiencies of our domestic economy—and that a whole range of government policies under Labor were in fact making it more difficult for our exporters to compete effectively within the region.

ANSWER.PARA: What Labor did was hide this failure to gain share within the fact that a greater share of our exports were going to the region. That was happening for a whole range of things—principally because of the growth within the region, so the markets were bigger and there was more opportunity. But, as a greater share of our exports were going to Asia, we were being outcompeted with others and our share of exports to Asia was in fact falling. That has been reiterated today by the research that has been published under the names of Professor Drysdale and Dr Lu.

We said time and time again to Labor—which of course would not listen because Senator Gareth Evans, as he then was, and successive trade ministers simple would not listen—that the problem was that we were not sufficiently competitive at the domestic economy. That is where, by contrast, we are putting in such great efforts. Firstly, we are trying to reduce the cost of business, so critical to Australian business being competitive internationally. Our policies of reducing the deficit through reducing public expenditure are designed to keep interest rates down, inflation down and taxes down to give our business the opportunity to be more competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have pushed the economy into contraction.

—Secondly, we have a major program for reform of our micro‐economy, in particular our workplace relations bill, Senator Cook. If you could do one thing that would assist Australian business to become more competitive within the region, it would be to support us in our industrial relations reform—give our business the opportunity to compete more effectively—and support us in relation to our reforms in transport, our reforms on the waterfront and reforms that enable the domestic economy to be more competitive.

ANSWER.PARA: When we add that to the opportunities we are seeking to further expand, the multilateral opportunity through the multilateral fora, such as the world trade office, and through regional efforts in APEC—and again I give Mr Fischer considerable credit for the initiative that he has shown in relation to APEC initiatives to expand our trade opportunity—and when all of these initiatives are drawn together, we will provide a basis within which Australian business can be more competitive and have a hope in the future to actually expand our share of Asian trade rather than to reduce it, which was the record of Labor. I ask that further questions be put on notice.

QUESTION.PARA: My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, Senator Newman. Can the minister confirm that over 30,000 Commonwealth seniors card holders will no longer be eligible to receive free hearing services through Australian Hearing Services as a result of the changes in the budget? Further, can the minister explain how the government reconciles these changes to eligibility requirements with its pre‐election commitment to maintain all current Commonwealth concessions?
Some 34,000 people currently hold Commonwealth Seniors Health cards.

Since introduction of this card in July 1994, just over 3,300 have sought access to entitlements under the Commonwealth Hearing Services Program. At present, between 90 and 100 applications are received monthly from this group.
The government's budget decisions exclude holders of a Commonwealth Seniors Health card from program eligibility from March 1997.

"It's a curious parallelism to announce substantial cuts and announce an inquiry at the same time but that's not to damn the inquiry or pre‐judge its outcome," he said.

ABC base funding by 1996/97 will be approximately $35 million greater than if the efficiency dividend had been applied. This enables efficiency gains to be applied to improving output.
The effect of triennial funding has been to provide the ABC with stable and predictable funding over the last seven years.

All major political parties support the triennial funding initiative. As outlined above, it provides the ABC with the ability to plan over a longer period while at the same time allowing it to retain any profits arising from its commercial activities.

What did this minister do when he got into government? He refuted those observations and commitments that he made at the time. He has imposed the efficiency dividend on the ABC and has wiped out triennial funding. The committee majority report, which was due essentially to Senator Alston who was driving it, said on page 96:
The continued exemption from the efficiency dividend helps provide greater planning certainty for the ABC's capital works program and is therefore supported by the Committee.

Senator Carr and I, in the minority report, supported the continuation of triennial funding and the continuation of the exemption from the efficiency dividend. We also supported the continuation of real funding levels for the ABC, the very same things that those who wrote the majority report committed themselves to and that the government committed itself to on election night.

Since then we have seen the greatest example of hypocrisy and backflip by you in this government—and God knows we have seen a heck of a lot of them. You announced that funding would be slashed by $66 million and future funding levels were put at great risk because of your announcements. In one fell swoop you undermined the confidence of the ABC and its employees, and the many hundreds of thousands of people in this country who rely upon the ABC, listen to it and support its independence. On page 98 of that report, again you stated:

The ABC needs surety of continued funding in order to provide the range of services expected under its statutory obligations. You cut funds to the ABC at the same time as you set up an inquiry under Mr Mansfield with respect to looking at charter activities and other matters of the ABC. At page 157 of the report you stated in your concluding remarks:

Despite the problems which the Committee identified in the ABC, the Committee believes that the basic structure of the ABC is sound and that the organisation is considerably stronger and more relevant to the Australian community now than it was ten years ago. PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
1. The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

2. The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

3. The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
4. Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
5. The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
6. The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
7. The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

8. The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with overaward gender based pay equity issues.
9. A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
10. Workers under state industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

Tertiary Students fear that the Government no longer view Tertiary Education as a priority. We seek stability in the education sector. We also oppose proposed increases in HECS and the introduction of upfront fees for some students. We believe that the proposed changes will be to the detriment of our educated and democratic society. We urge the Parliament to consider these points, keeping in mind that the future of thousands of families will be affected by these changes.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme

The petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws attention to the Senate that we strongly reject any increase in the Independent rate of Austudy to age 25, and any move to abolish Austudy and Abstudy to create one common Youth Allowance.
This is on the basis that:

The numerous barriers which exist in the higher education system for many groups in society make it essential for the Federal Government to provide support to those who most need assistance to attend university. The extra three years that students must remain dependent on their families presumes that families provide unconditional support for their studying children. The underlying basis for this change is especially flawed given that traditional notions of the `family' can no longer be upheld. And furthermore it is unreasonable to expect families to support their children at university when they may not have the financial means to do so.

The Federal Government is encouraging students to take out loans which will further increase their total debt on top of HECS. It must be recognised that it is extremely difficult to study and work at the same time in order to cover all the associated expenses of education, and without some financial support, many students would not be able to attend university.

By increasing the age of Independence, the Federal Government is discouraging identified equity groups such as women, people from lower socio‐economic backgrounds, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and mature age students from participating in higher education. These groups are shown to participate at a disparate rate in higher education due to factors such as a lack of financial support.

There is no guarantee that a Youth Allowance will provide adequate income support for tertiary students. Further, unemployment benefits should not be means tested on parental income, given that the recipients of these benefits are taxpayers and citizens in their own right.

The current forced repatriation of Vietnamese refugees in Asian camps has led to tremendous sufferings. In the last few months up to mid‐July 1996, these include: at least 5 reported refugee deaths by suicide, shooting, and beating; some 80 refugees passively resisted a forced repatriation operation on 29 June in Thailand by stabbing their own stomachs; suicide attempts by at least a dozen refugees when forcibly repatriated from Malaysia during May; and thousands of refugees have also suffered injuries, physical and sexual abuses by personnel conducting forced repatriation exercises;
2. Recognised refugees forcibly repatriated:

A number of people recognised by UN High Commissioner for Refugees as refugees have been forcibly repatriated, for example Mr Nguyen Huu Nghia PST8452 from Thailand on 29 June 1996, who was then harassed and put under surveillance by Vietnamese authorities.
3. Returnees persecuted—Report published:

Under the Comprehensive Plan of Action, UNHCR was obliged to monitor their safety. Despite UNHCR's attempts to cover up incidents of persecution which it is fully aware of, evidence to the contrary has started to surface. In July 1996 a report compiling such evidence—public information from Vietnamese internal security forces, leaked documents from UNHCR, and testimony from victims—was released by the Vietnamese Australian community.
Your petitioners respectfully ask tat the Australian Parliament urgently express its grave concerns about the use of forced repatriation, particularly of recognised refugees.
