INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 16 September 1996, from Senator Kernot:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The continuing ideological determination of the Government to proceed with the sale of one‐third of Telstra despite Telstra's outstanding performance in respect of profitability and efficiency in public ownership.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The continuing ideological determination of the Government to proceed with the sale of one‐third of Telstra despite Telstra's outstanding performance in respect of profitability and efficiency in public ownership.

It is indeed a matter of urgency that we have this debate this afternoon. We have to do all in our power to force this government to think again about its ideological obsession with the privatisation of Telstra.

Bit by bit, the spurious arguments that this government has mounted month after month are being dismantled. No matter what the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, might say that Mr Blount is saying, the fact of the matter is that the government has relied on three main arguments to persuade us to allow it to sell Telstra.

Firstly, it has said that this will lead to an increase in public savings, but that has been debunked by this government's own National Commission of Audit. The commission rejected the cashflow based accounting method used by this government, saying that it does not give a true picture of its value.

Secondly, the government has told us time and time again that we need to privatise it because that will benefit consumers. It does not say that it means business consumers; it pretends that it is all consumers. But this argument too has been demolished by the simple fact that the government wants to bring forward legislation that will put in place regulation, because regulation—not privatisation—is the key to safeguarding consumer interests.

But thirdly, and most of all, this government has relied very heavily on the argument of efficiency. That argument has been shot down over time, but particularly on Friday when Telstra told us that it has reduced its costs per line to eight per cent below the world average and that those costs are falling.

Today Senator Alston added the other argument when he lectured us that you cannot do anything about spending this windfall, which does not really exist, because you might erode the budget bottom line. Senator Hill brought out this argument as well. I want to take one second to ask about the National Party's attack on the budget bottom line.

What about the National Party's opposition to the reef tax? What about its reintroduction of the shipping grants, with $32 million to BHP? What about its maintenance of the highly inefficient diesel fuel rebate to the tune of $1.3 billion? The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, wants to spend this windfall—which Senator Alston and the Treasurer, Mr Costello, say does not exist—on the people's convention. But I think Mr Fischer can read the budget papers.

Treasurer Costello said in question time in the other place today that I have made an error about my claim of a windfall. I do not believe that I have. I believe that, based on the year to year result announced on Friday, Telstra has contributed an extra $840 million in dividends and company taxes over what it did the year before. Yes, part of that has already been paid into Treasury coffers late last financial year, and now the rest will be paid. But it is more than was forecast in the budget—ask Tim Fischer—and that is the point.

How much more Treasury will receive will depend on Telstra's half year statement after December. But the only way the Treasury forecast of 2.7 per cent dividend payment and the 7.9 per cent company tax payment could be met—the only way we could reach that forecast—is if there were a massive reduction in Telstra profitability over the next six months. Mr Blount said on Friday that this will not happen; Telstra investment will rise and its costs will fall. Is the minister predicting a massive slump for Telstra over the next six months, because that is the only way that this government's conservative estimates on forecasting can be met. Treasury has a very poor record on this, having underestimated company tax receipts for four years. It has also understated Telstra and Australia Post dividends for the last two years.

Let us return to the efficiency argument. No matter what Senator Alston might say in his remarks to come, this government has lectured us ad nauseam on Telstra's inefficiencies. They have talked Telstra down month after month. I can quote Senator Alston on 6 May, when he said that the reason his government wanted privatisation was that `it forces efficiencies on the company'. Senator Short said on 7 May:
The fundamental reason for the partial privatisation of Telstra is to make Telstra more efficient and competitive.
Mr Peter Costello on 1 August:
The principal reasons for asset sales are greater efficiency and better services.

Let us look at the matter of the efficiency of Telstra in public ownership. The fact is that Telstra has dramatically improved efficiency and productivity in recent years. A study coordinated by the Industry Commission last year found that Telstra had reduced its prices by 16 per cent in real terms since 1989‐90 while doubling labour productivity, and that it has increased payments to government by more than 60 per cent since 1990‐91. The Bureau of Industry Economics estimates that Telstra's total factor productivity, which measures both labour and capital productivity, grew at an average rate of 6.3 per cent between 1979‐80 and 1993‐94.

The point is that these achievements are well above the national average and have been made at the same time as maintaining Telstra's community service obligations. If you look at some further facts from Telstra's announcement on Friday, you find that Telstra's unit costs have been cut by 10 per cent during the past financial year and are now eight per cent below the average for world telecommunications companies. These figures come from a cost efficiency benchmarking in a study by the consultant group Mercer.

What about the other measures of success? There is a return on capital of 22.9 per cent and a return on assets of 17.9 per cent. These are both healthy indicators and we should remember, when dealing with the government's attempts to talk Telstra down and talking about after 1997, that BZW, allowing for a 20 per cent loss of market share, still says that Telstra will have an average profit of about 16 per cent over the next few years. I put to the Senate that we are asking the government to think again about their ideological obsession with privatisation. There have been no decent economic arguments advanced to this stage. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was waiting for the substantive arguments. BZW's analysis today states:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost reduction program has not yet had effect. Telstra has begun to address its cost issues, but results are too early to impact.

I think that is fairly important to recognise. The quotes that Senator Kernot referred to, which presumably are from Alan Kohler's latest article, relate to the return on assets and the return on capital. They are not the most relevant indicators of efficiency. One needs to look at return on equity. Telstra could have done a lot better in that regard. Its return on equity was 17.9 per cent and world's best practice levels are much higher. Telecom New Zealand has a return on equity of 34 per cent and AT&T has a return on equity of 35 per cent. In other words, it is almost double Telstra's return. If Telstra's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation were as high as Telecom New Zealand then the bottom line would have increased by many billions. On it goes.

It does not prove anything to argue that somehow, over the last six or so years Telstra has reduced prices, there has been an increase in payments to the government of 60 per cent or that the total factor productivity has gone up by an average of 6.3 per cent, which is well above the average in the economy, because we are dealing with a unique industry. Technological changes come along almost every second day and they have dramatic effects on the increase in productivity and performance. Cable modems are supposed, for example, to increase the rate of access for data by 100 times. Digital switching has made an enormous difference, as has optical fibre transmission.

Telcos around the world are gaining very significantly from technological progress but not from labour market efficiency—and certainly not when they have the access lines per employee ratio that Telstra currently has. Telstra acknowledges this. It has set itself the task of trying to make those improvements. You will never make those improvements if you simply allow yourself to be at the beck and call and whim of the government.

The government does not believe in intervention. You know what Labor was like. A few years ago they had to approve every press release that was put out by Telstra. That is a recipe for disaster. You would have the government telling what is supposedly a commercial operation what to do and how to do it. That is why you have regulation, but they ignore the regulation. They want to give directions.
The reasons we want to go down this path have been spelt out by many commentators and I will refer to a couple of those.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economic cheer squad.
—We will come to this in a moment. There has to come a stage when you say to yourself, `If every intelligent commentator sees a virtue in going down a particular path'—
—Who are they? Who do they represent?
—That is the accumulated body of wisdom that we happen to have in this country.
—Is Kohler one of them?

—As you know, on almost every issue you can find someone on one side of the argument or someone on the other. This is particularly so in the field of economics. It is very rare to get even a relative degree of unanimity. Virtually every economic commentator, I suppose with the exception of Kenneth Davidson, sees the virtue in privatisation.
—Kohler.
—No, Alan Kohler does not. Alan Kohler takes the view that Telstra ought to be privatised.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting you raised that. You should look at an article that he wrote eight days earlier in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not mean to imply that selling Telstra is not worth doing or would be a bad thing to do. As the Age editorial correctly argued the other day, the business of government is to govern, not to run businesses.
Do not quote Alan Kohler to me as someone who is opposed to privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is changing his mind.

—I am telling you what he said eight days ago. If you read his article carefully, you will find that what he is really saying is that the timing is not quite right. He would rather do it later rather than sooner because he thinks that there is a lot of money to be made by the government if Telstra is going to continue to return boom profits. That is not an argument against privatisation. That is simply saying that you can get your hands on the cash earlier and spend it in all sorts of ways now, profligate and otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: The longer the process takes, the more capacity you have to take advantage of that. In any event, whatever price you get—whether it is $8 billion or $11 billion as some commentators are now saying—it means that you are capitalising on that future income earning stream. You are not wasting it. You are missing out on it. It is simply paid in as the net present value of that stream of earnings. That money is then available to do whatever you feel is necessary.

We take the view that our responsibility is to pay off the public debt rather than tip it in as the previous government did with all the privatisations that it embraced. I think Senator Kernot put out a press release on the airports corporation saying, `Yet again another privatisation supported by Labor.' In other words, they have privatised everything that moves. They would have been in this like Flynn if they had half a chance. The only reason they are not doing it is sheer naked political opportunism. It suits their political purposes to fabricate an argument that says that this is not good for Australia. It is good for Australia.
I want to address the question of ideology. Before I do that, I will complete the point about commentators and their arguments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're the ideologue. Is this the Albania quote?
—Get McDonald's name right and I might hear what you have to say. The Australian states:

BREAK.PARA: This newspaper supports the sale of Telstra for four main reasons. First, state ownership in the dynamic global telecommunications market is an anachronism among developed nations where a competitive environment exists. Second, the nation pays a price for state ownership because of the lack of a vibrant telecommunications sector and the Stock Exchange restricts the development of capital markets. Third, there is an inherent contradiction in having a deregulated telecommunications sector while Telstra remains in public hands. Finally—
and this is a blunt political point—
the coalition went into the last election with a clearly explained policy. The electorate voted overwhelmingly for the coalition's platform and handed the new government a mandate to go ahead.

Of course, there are many other reasons. We have just dealt in passing with the savings argument. I dealt earlier on with the conflict of interest argument between government as regulator and government as shareholder beneficiary. But Frank Blount himself—and I know you do not want to hear it again—spelt out five arguments about: increased commercial focus and accountability; allowing Telstra to better balance and judge investment trade‐offs; regulatory and policy transparency and certainty; easier access to capital; and scope for incentive schemes for management and staff, thus increasing staff motivation. These are all the very sorts of reasons why virtually every other country in the world has gone down this path.

I ask myself—and, Senator Kernot, I would like you to address this in your reply—what does ideology mean in this day and age? Does it mean belief in a political system such as socialism on the one hand or capitalism on the other hand? Does it mean some sort of religious fervour or commitment? Or does it, indeed, mean a determination to pursue a point of view irrespective of all the arguments to the contrary?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it does.

—If it does then you have the task of explaining why we have countries like Argentina, Chile and the Czech Republic all over the shop in ideology. You have Peru. Where does Peru stand? You have the Bahamas.
—They were all losing money.

—Not every country in the world needs the money, Senator Schacht. Germany is not losing money. Germany is privatising. France is not losing money. Hungary, Indonesia, Ghana, Latvia—the list goes on. If ever you would have thought someone had an ideological point of view, it would be my mate Fidel. You would have thought Fidel had a certain ideological view of the world. Fidel is into privatisation in spades.
—We've never supported the communists. You're the only one who is.

—The reason that countries across the ideological spectrum believe in privatisation is not because somehow they have all been seduced by wicked multinationals or they have been belted over the head by Age editorialists—and the Age is on our side on this one too. They are going down that path because of the nonsense of governments running businesses when they know they cannot do it half as well as the private sector. And you can have it both ways because, to the extent that you need to superimpose a set of restrictions and regulations, you do it by legislation. That is what we propose to do. That is what other countries do. That is why they all have their USOs. That is why they all have their variations on consumer protection arrangements. It can be done, and it is being done around the world.

BREAK.PARA: So, when we talk about ideology, I would have thought that, in the face of that overwhelming evidence, it is in the interests of consumers that it does provide efficiency gains which then translate into lower prices and better quality of service. The onus is very much on you to show who is being ideological in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) just said that all the economic commentators are supporting the government's view on privati sation. I have to accept that there are some. But when he said `all the commentators', I just happened to pick up what was in the Sun‐Herald yesterday by Peter Robinson under the headline, `Telstra deal is madness', and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's plans to sell part of Telstra had their origins in undisguised opportunism, passed through a period of black political farce and are now being engulfed by sheer madness.
How a rational administration could get itself into such an imbroglio is difficult to comprehend.

That is not a bad kick for goal, Senator Alston, from Peter Robinson in his article. Of course, you may claim that he ought to go to Albania or Cuba and see what Fidel is doing. Fidel Castro or the leftover of the Enver Hoxha regime in Albania seems to be the last person you can quote as a defence of why we should privatise Telstra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pinochet. He quoted Pinochet.
—Of course, Pinochet in Chile in the 1980s.
—Pinochet actually gave the game away about eight years ago.

—I am glad Senator Alston interjected. Yes, he gave the game away nearly a decade ago. But your own department of communications, when asked in the Senate inquiry to justify the privatisation of Telstra, gave the examples of the privatisation in Chile under Pinochet in the 1980s. They actually quoted an electricity company in 1981 at the height of the Pinochet regime in Chile. That was the empirical evidence that your department gave. They could not find anything else. They had to rely on Pinochet. Not exactly a ringing endorsement of comparison between Chile and Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: All those places they have privatised, including the telecommunications company which they sold to Alan Bond—I am not sure you want to defend Alan Bond around the place; I understand he is now in gaol—all of those companies that your department quoted, were all losing money. Of course they were going to be privatised—because they were losing money.

BREAK.PARA: The big difference with Telstra is that it is a profitable company. It has just declared the biggest corporate profit in Australia's history. Ordinary Australians are asking why you want to sell the biggest profitable company in Australia. Even your mate Alan Kohler, who you are starting to bag, quotes it as having, in the last 12 months, strongly got on top of its costs. Senator Kernot has already quoted him. And I quote from his article:
Telstra's unit costs have been cut by 10 per cent during the past financial year and, on its own reckoning, are now 8 per cent below the average for world telecommunications companies . . .

That is something the minister did not want to hear because it destroys his ideological obsession of wanting to privatise a most successful company in Australia. It is all outlined in the documents tabled by Telstra on Friday. Here is a company whose revenues grew from $14 billion to $15.2 billion—revenues up by eight per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's nothing to do with efficiency.

—I don't know whether you have read this, Senator Alston, but when you get down to the bottom line their profit went up. Operating profit after tax and minority interest went from $1.7 billion to $2.3 billion. That is a $600 million increase—a 31 per cent increase. If that had been a private company, all your mates down at the Stock Exchange would have been busting their guts to go and buy shares.

BREAK.PARA: There were various articles in Saturday's financial papers, including one by Mark Westfield in the Weekend Australian, which said that Ziggy Zwitkowski, the chief executive of Optus, would look at these figures from Telstra with some interest and concern because this is a result that, if you had listened to the minister only a couple of months ago, would have been impossible to consider because, as Senator Kernot said, since you have been minister you have done nothing but bag Telstra, its employees—

TALK.START.PARA: —He called it a sheltered workshop.

—A sheltered workshop was one of the phrases we got from Senator Alston. There would not be a com pany in Australia today that would mind being a sheltered workshop if its profit went up by 31 per cent. That is what you are trying to deny, that this company has made a substantial contribution to the revenues of your government for the people of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Yesterday, Tim Fischer, the Acting Prime Minister, spilt the beans and said, `Well, the extra money would be useful for the government's bottom line.' Senator Alston said quite the opposite. He said, `It will have no advantage for the government's bottom line; all these figures, all these increased profits, are mythical; they don't count.' Today, in trying to give the Senate an answer—which was gobbledegook at its worst—for over four minutes he tried to explain how $600 million increased profit, an increased dividend of several hundred million to the Australian government and increased taxes to the Australian government did not mean anything; there was no improvement.

Tim Fischer—two‐minute Tim as he is affectionately called by some—got it right. He said, `There is extra money available to the Australian people through the bottom line of the budget.' Now Senator Alston does not want to concede that because his argument in favour of privatisation gets wrecked.
Last Friday night on the 7.30 Report, Alan Kohler—the commentator Senator Alston has already quoted today as saying he has generally been in favour of privatisation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Eight days ago, before the—
—Yes. Then again, in the interview with Kerry O'Brien, Alan Kohler said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . they've now got their unit costs, their costs, operating expenses per line, below the average of the world telecommunications companies for the first time. Previously, like a year ago, they were well above the average and now, thanks to that 10 per cent cut, they're 8 per cent below the average of the world and they're planning now to stay there.

They were Kohler's remarks, that they have got their costs down and that that is improving the bottom line. He was asked about what impact this excellent result from Telstra would have on people like Senator Alston and the government, and Alan Kohler said:

Well, I do think Senator Alston is probably feeling a bit uncomfortable here. He has been arguing—and it's almost his only argument that's left—that Telstra has to be sold in order for it to become efficient, otherwise it will get trampled on by British Telecom and AT&T. Well, clearly, Telstra is becoming efficient now, so that argument is falling over.

The major argument to justify privatisation which this minister has put in this place for six months—that Telstra is an inefficient and unprofitable organisation—has now fallen over, says Alan Kohler.

Another argument that has been put by some supporters of privatisation, including the minister, is that after 1 July next year there will be a much more open market in telecommunications, that other carriers will be able to start and that Telstra will not be able to beat all this extra competition.

During the Senate inquiry, those of us on the committee asked a number of people, including those in favour of privatisation, what they thought the future of Telstra would be post‐July next year. Overwhelmingly, whilst they could not give an accurate figure to the last decimal point, they all conceded that Telstra would maintain its position as the dominant carrier—80 per cent of the market.
In the report which BZW produced earlier this year about Telstra—which the minister just quoted in his remarks—it said about the 1 July 1997 deregulated market:

New carriers after July 1997 and the larger service providers in aggregate will take a gradually increasing share of the corporate, business, long distance and international markets (in the order of 5‐10% over five years).
On that figure Telstra would probably drop to just over 80 per cent of the total market. Then the report goes on to say:
Telstra's own growth is likely to continue to exceed that of these players in aggregate.

So BZW, in favour of privatisation, certainly made it clear that, despite the extra competition post‐July next year, Telstra will still be growing stronger. Even though its percentage point of the marketplace may drop five or 10 per cent, as the market for telecommunications is growing—according to the evidence we had before us in the inquiry, and no‐one has disputed it—at about 15 per cent per annum, Telstra's revenues, turnover, profit, size, the value of its company, will go up accordingly. It will not diminish as a total company.

So, despite new competition coming in, Telstra in the foreseeable future will be the dominant carrier. For ideological reasons, Senator Alston wants to hand that dominant carrier over to his mates in the private sector, including some foreign owners, to get their hands on the increasing profit.

The final thing I want to comment on is that in the annual results given last Friday it was said that, in 1996‐97, Telstra has put aside $1.1 billion for redundancies. This is to help pay off the 22,000 people who will be leaving Telstra. Apparently in one year Telstra will be able to pay that amount of money. It may well reduce its profit for a year but, in the following year, all those people will be off the bottom line. Those people will no longer be a cost; therefore, there will be an extra billion dollars of profit.

If that is the outcome the government wants, to reduce the costs in Telstra and to get rid of all of those workers, and there is going to be a big increase in profit accordingly, why can that profit not stay with all Australian people and go into the public revenues to be used in socially useful programs, including retraining programs for Telstra employees? The minister has said that the marketplace will pick up—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before us is in regard to the ideological determination to proceed with the sale of one-third of Telstra. `Ideological' may not be quite the right term; perhaps the term should be `bias'. `Ideological' implies that there is a system of ideas and beliefs which someone or some group supports in a committed and integral way, maybe even in a blind and blinkered way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that there is a blind belief in the market—in this case, the international market—despite all the work presented by John Kenneth Galbraith and others in the 1970s to indicate that we have long since entered the age of mega‐corporations who are large enough to control markets. An ideological belief in the international communications market guaranteeing efficiency is very hard to swallow. If your definition of efficiency includes consumer outcomes in terms of access and equity, evidence would suggest the contrary.

Does the government really believe that public interest and international corporate interests are the same? I do not believe there is any but the most tenuous of real commitments to ideas by this government. Personally, I find them more cynical in support of a pragmatic political approach. We can see this in the way they have linked this bill to short-term support of environmental programs while gutting recurrent funding for the environment. Clearly, this is a fairly crass approach with very little real integrity—ideological or otherwise.

I would say that the continued push for the sale is evidence of the power of vested interests rather than ideology. Big business, Murdoch, Microsoft or Intel, would like us to sell Telecom. It is in their interest. And, yes, they have a global influence.

It is clearly not a decision based on economics. The economics show that Telecom is being operated very profitably, thank you. If one believes that efficiency and service delivery translates into profit, then it appears to be operated very efficiently, and that is the opinion of various international operators.

So, if we have a profitable, efficient company operated by government in a fairly accountable way, where is the economic advantage in selling this company and destroying the income stream? Professor John Quiggin has shown that the income stream is currently more valuable than the value of any debt retirement likely from the sale, even at a lower level of profit and optimistic sale price. So it is not an economic decision.Let us clear the air and state that, no matter what the current pretence and protestations, certainly the one-third sale is only a first tranche to total privatisation.

It is clearly not a decision based on the public interest. It is not in the interest of the public to lose control of a very profitable enterprise which is also an essential part of the social and economic infrastructure of the country. The likely outcome, as with financial deregulation, is competition. The general outcome of competition is that some company wins, some companies lose and in the struggle public interest becomes expendable. At worst, you end up with a private monopoly. At best, you end up with something like the petrol cartel situation, where a handful of companies get together to set prices once market share is determined.

Telecommunication is bigger than petrol production. Market entry is more difficult. There are never any `Ma `n Pa' telecommunications companies. They are not local or regional; they are national or, increasingly, global. We are not talking about competition in terms of the village market analogy of Adam Smith; we are talking about the Australian front of the global war between half a dozen competitors.

The government is not just ideological; it is supporting specific interests. It is supporting the interests of global corporations against the interest of the public and against economic self-interest. It is willing to make any deals in whatever way it must in order to serve its corporate masters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's debate there are a number of issues that I would like to canvass, not the least of which is the employment issue that has been raised as part of this debate both through the Senate hearings and in constant reference to this whole issue in the chamber. In so doing I would just like to make four statements on the issue of privatisation itself:

SPEECH.PARA: The primary objective driving the privatisation program is to make Australia an efficient, internationally competitive economy—and that means introducing competition into our enterprises and into our market sector.

The focus of debate on efficiency measures such as privatisation and competition policy is often on job losses, but it is more important to realise that the efficiency gain from the pursuit of competition creates jobs.
Privatisation is not pursued because of a New Right ideology that says government ownership has no benefits and must be relinquished at all costs.

Privatisation, for instance, can strengthen the performance of enterprises by allowing private capital injections, as happened with the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, and international alliances to be formed, as with the sale of 25 per cent of Qantas to British Airways . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told us that, Senator Knowles?

—I am very glad that you asked, Senator Abetz. Those quotes do not come from the Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. John Howard, or from my honourable colleague here with me today Senator Alston. They are actually quotes from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley. They are his quotes on the whole issue of privatisation which one could find fairly breathtaking, given what we have just heard from the shadow minister for communications. Labor is now in opposition and opposed to privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: But I want to move on to the important area of employment, because Labor is just as hypocritical in that area. Of course that quote from Mr Beazley did in fact say that `privatisation fits in with the government's broader imperative to create jobs'. So there we have another quote from Mr Beazley about creating jobs, yet right throughout the Telstra inquiry and this debate today we have had both of the opposition parties trying to create an impression that jobs are just going to disappear.

Four myths have in fact been perpetuated throughout this debate. One is that the government's partial privatisation policy is responsible for employment reductions in Telstra. Wrong! The second one is that employment reductions must be accompanied by industrial action. That of course will happen only if the Labor Party and the Democrats continue to wind up the unions, who themselves have admitted that job losses are not about the privatisation issue but about technological change. Those are the quotes that are coming directly from the trade unions associated with the Labor Party and associated with the telecommunications industry.

The third myth is that employment throughout the telecommunications industry will disappear. It is clearly not so according to those professionals in the telecommunications area who gave evidence to the committee only a couple of months ago.

The fourth myth is that partial privatisation will reduce employment in regional areas. If that is so, why was it that so many people from country areas gave us evidence to the contrary? Why is it that so many people in country Australia want to see the partial privatisation of Telstra so that they can get more telecommunications services and facilities into rural and regional Australia?

Employment levels in Telstra continue to fall, and will continue to fall for some time, from back when the Labor Party were in government. Let us not forget that the Labor government scrubbed out about 23,000 jobs in Telstra. That is virtually the identical number that we are talking about now. Did they quibble about it? Did they quibble about the jobs in the Commonwealth Bank when they privatised it? Did they quibble about jobs when they were talking about the privatisation of CSL or Qantas? No! The question arises only when they are now in opposition and there is to be partial privatisation of a government instrumentality. Here it is—and it is different!

Actual staffing numbers are fully determined not by the government but by the Telstra board and management as part of the corporate planning process. Employment levels in Telstra are an outcome of corporate planning—not of government policy—and that corporate planning takes into account customer demand; the requirements for capital investment in network development; productivity, including the effects of technological changes; financial performance; investment opportunities; and likely market behaviour by competitors.

Technology in particular, as I said before, is reducing employment levels in telecommunications companies around the world. The Queensland Branch Secretary of the CEPU acknowledged, in his evidence before the Senate inquiry, its effect on employment. When asked by Senator Tierney whether those job losses in Telstra are primarily driven by technology, Mr McLean responded:
Yes. The major driver is technology.
The same question was put to another union leader, Mr Colin Cooper, Divisional President of the CEPU, and he responded:
On the figures that have been put to us, we have agreed in some areas that there can be staff reductions. We have been through all these processes with new technology.

To listen to the debate today and what has been said in the months that have preceded it, one would believe that this has come about only because of the whole notion of the partial privatisation of Telstra. The fact is that Telstra remains uncompetitive in a number of areas. If the Labor Party and the Democrats are happy to make sure Telstra remains uncompetitive, they can continue on this frolic that they have been on for some time.

They can also continue on the frolic of perpetuating these myths, such as that employment reductions must be accompanied by industrial action. But that will happen only if the Labor Party and the Democrats continue to encourage such industrial action. I was unaware that the Labor Party had encouraged such industrial action when they made privatisation moves when in government. The staff reductions went largely unnoticed by most of the community because they occurred without significant industrial disputation and primarily through voluntary redundancies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And re-employed them.

—Ah, I am glad you have mentioned that, Senator Carr, because, yes, they are re-employable. Have a look at the evidence that a number of people gave the committee about the employment prospects for people in the industry who might lose their jobs. You are saying that sustainable employment throughout the telecommunications industry will disappear. That is simply not true, and you know it to be not true. Mr Horsley of the Australian Telecommunications Users Group said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make the point that the industry is desperately short of people. We cannot find them—we put ads in the paper and our members are looking for people and cannot find them . . . Our experience has been that there is substantial demand for employment and if changes . . . in Telstra result in fewer employees, those employees will pick up work, without a doubt, outside.
That evidence given to the committee has been totally and utterly neglected by the Labor Party. Mr Perkins of the Service Providers Action Network said:

I can sit before you today and say that, in the company and amongst SPAN members, we have a great deal of trouble finding suitably qualified staff. I think that many of the people that will come out of Telstra as a result of this will certainly find employment within the telecommunications industry.
These people are having difficulty finding staff, yet the Labor Party continues to say that there are no employment opportunities for those who lose their jobs.

The fourth myth, that partial privatisation will reduce employment in regional areas, is just that—a myth. The spread of sustainable employment opportunities to hybrid telecommunications industries will not stop there. It will affect the entire economy. The telecommunications industry is very important in rural and regional areas. Many industries have shown they are able to grow and develop in rural and regional areas throughout the world, and that could translate here. For example, in the United States large companies have relocated functions such as airline reservations and insurance processing to rural areas where there are lower rental charges. It provides job opportunities at lower costs and with greater housing availability. And those jobs will be picked up. To say otherwise is completely and utterly false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate indicates that, as a result of the decisions that were announced by the Telstra board on Friday, without any doubt Telstra is far too valuable to sell. The proposition we have before us highlights that this government's ideological obsession with the market and with the destruction of this public enterprise is based on one proposition: if it is in the public sector, it is bad; if it is in the private sector, it is good.

PARA.BREAK: The results on Friday indicate the complete total nonsense that that proposition involves. One of the biggest profits ever in this country was announced: a 31 per cent increase in the profits of Telstra and a return to government of $1.36 billion. It clearly indicates above all that the proposition to sell Telstra is essential ly based on a wrong assumption. There is no empirical evidence to support the conclusion that Australians would be better off, that Telstra would be better off, or that in any way this country would be served, by the proposition that is being advanced by this government. This clearly indicates that the wheels are very much falling off the government's cart in terms of its proposition to privatise Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: We see an attempt being made by this government essentially to kill the goose that lays the golden egg. We are seeing a proposition which, in the most obscene manner, suggests that we put forward $1 billion for redundancy payments, and then use the proceeds of the sale of Telstra to finance an essentially recurrent program for the environment. What an obscenity that is! What an obscenity it is to suggest that, in this era of high unemployment, we can put to our public enterprises that they have no social responsibility and that they should move forward with a program based on headcount figures—ideological assumptions about the costs of the telecommunications service—to remove some 22,000 Australians from the employment of Telstra.

Right across the board, we see people not normally regarded as left‐wingers, not normal socialists—people like Alan Kohler, well‐known for the sorts of policies that he has advanced in support of Jeff Kennett in Victoria—indicating that a huge Telstra profit sets a few bells ringing. `The Telstra deal is madness,' says Peter Robinson, another well‐known radical. These are very, very conservative economists. Alan Kohler indicates that it is too good an earner to sell. That is his comment in regard to Telstra.

Now within the government itself very substantial differences are emerging between Mr Fischer and Senator Alston over what should be done in regard to the dividends received. Laura Tingle has indicated that this is an enormously difficult problem for the government because these massive growths in profits are being announced at the same time as some of the greatest levels of sackings ever known in the history of this country. We are seeing a program of management initiated redundancies as the Telstra Corporation is being carved up, quite contrary to the propositions that were put to the Australian people before the last election.

We see even such obscenities as are being proposed by Telstra through their Mercury privatisation task force: that there should be, if necessary, the outsourcing of Australian jobs overseas. We see it quite clearly in the statements made by Mr Blount last Friday night, when he said, `If it is cheaper, we will do it. And if it is the best practice.'

The Mercury papers show quite clearly that this company is currently engaged in a high‐level scoping study to remove operator services away from centres in Australia to overseas destinations. So we are concerned about regional jobs, all right—regional jobs in the Philippines! That is hardly what you would say to be in the best interest of this country.

We are noticing again and again that this government's obsession with the market is distorting what is in the national interest and in the social interest of this country. For instance, in regard to project Mercury, an announced program is under way to remove so many jobs from Telstra, which goes far and beyond any possible effect of technological change. We are seeing here a drive to reduce the bottom line in Telstra so the prospectus looks good, and that is being driven by the scoping study, which is being directed by this government.

For this government to stand back and wash their hands of it, to say it is just a management decision, is a complete nonsense. To say that somehow or another the unions have been involved in this is completely nonsense. The quotes that are being used are totally distorted from what was actually said. The union has indicated again and again that we see that technology can be used to reduce the tyranny of distance. It can be used to produce an economic advantage for regional Australia. But that is not how it is being used; it is being used to increase the levels of concentration in centralised locations such as Melbourne and Sydney.

Just as it can be used to reduce the distances to improve the situation in regional Australia, it is being used to reduce the distances so that overseas companies can penetrate Australian markets in such a way as to reduce employment prospects for Australians. Hence the use of the Philippines as a source for our operator‐assisted services. When people ring up, they do not necessarily speak to someone in Roma or Burnie. Given the technology that is available, the services can be operated from Manila.

We see the minister saying, `Let us have a look at the world best practice.' And what do we notice in regard to the financial performance of Telstra? The committee report makes it very clear. We see in terms of profit—the pretax return on capital, return on investment—that the Australian result is 22 per cent. The world best practice is over 20 per cent, so on that measure Telstra is above world best practice. On interest cover, it is well over world best practice, and on debt ratios, return on average equity and profit margin. It is all detailed in the report. Instead of trying to talk down the achievements of this company, you would expect this government to be talking about what real achievements are being made by Australians and what is one of Australia's and potentially one of the world's great companies. We should also appreciate the contribution it is making to Australian society.

The minister constantly talks about the situation in America for a comparison with overseas companies. But, for instance, Bell Atlantic is a company that serves a market of 19 million lines on the US east coast and enjoys revenue of some $18 billion. During the period from 1992 to 1994, the company cut 1,600 employees from its payroll. As a result, the number of access lines per employee rose 7.6 per cent. Is what we see an improvement in service? No.

The service quality statistics file with the US Federal Communications Commission suggests that these efficiencies have been achieved at a significant cost to the consumer. Between 1992 and 1994, for instance, the company report rate rose sharply. If you look at that in some detail, you see that the situation for consumers has deteriorated markedly. So not only do we see cuts in jobs, cuts to regional centres and cuts to the economies of those regions in terms of a multiplier effect, but we see that a loss of service results as well.

Look at US West—that great comparison—which has one of the most notorious employment and customer service records in the United States. That is being used as the great golden model on which we should benchmark Telstra's performance. In 1989, 58,000 employees were engaged in its US operations. By the end of 1993 that number had fallen to 9,000. It is now down to 4,500. A similar experience occurred in New Zealand, where the number of employees has been cut in half. International experience tells us again and again that there will be a loss of jobs, a loss of community service, a loss of customer service. This model is being pursued by the government.

Already, the policies of this government are having a distorting impact on Telstra's operations. It is quite clear that the ideological obsession this government has with privatisation has more to do with its faith in the market and less to do with its commitment to Australian society and the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time available to me, I want to make a few points in response to the arguments we have heard today. I think Senator Alston summed it up best when he said after Senator Kernot's speech that we are still waiting for the arguments. We certainly heard the arguments when we were out holding committee hearings. We heard clear and convincing evidence from experts—not from amateurs—that such a change as the part‐privatisation of Telstra will lead to an easier access to capital, create greater motivation for staff, benefit consumers on costs and services, and improve efficiencies of Telstra to better achieve world best practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits of privatisation have probably been summed up best by Kim Beazley. Let me quote from his 1994 National Press Club speech:
Trying to preserve the past—
which is what Senator Carr would like to do—

BREAK.PARA: may seem to be the best way to protect jobs, but in the longer term it could be a major impediment to achieving a productive future.

The nub of this debate is the way in which a more efficient Telstra, through the private injection of capital, can improve services and drive down costs. The very flimsy arguments that we have had today, which have centred on the fact that Telstra now has a large profit, miss the whole point of what is happening in the area of telecommunications in this country. In the next year, we are going to be moving to a regime where a number of companies are involved. Already AT&T and Sprint are saddling up to become part of this market.

We need a much more efficient Telstra. They have made great profits; that is terrific. But by Telstra's own admission, they are 25 per cent off the pace. If they are competing with AT&T and Sprint as well as Optus, they cannot afford to be 25 per cent off the pace. They make great profits, but they also have huge amounts of capital. Only the more efficient operations that will come from a partly privatised Telstra will bring about a situation where we have a great Australian communications company which can not only survive but also compete in the international marketplace. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate and how it is voted on will make not the slightest difference as to whether or not one‐third of Telstra is sold. I have some difficulties with the motion before us; I will mention a couple of them.

SPEECH.PARA: After Senator Alston made his statement last Monday fortnight, I wrote to him and challenged him as to whether the government were ideologically motivated or whether they just wanted to have the $8 billion. What the proponents of this motion have forgotten, so far as I have heard in this debate thus far, is that the one‐third sale of Telstra is to obtain $8 billion, $7 billion of which would go to debt redemption. That is something that has got to be thought about as well. I have offered a solution to that—that we go along the redeemable preference share line. You could have your cake and eat it too. I am not going to go into that because I have not got time. I am not convinced just yet that the government is totally ideologically motivated.

We have heard about outstanding performance in respect of profitability and efficiency in public ownership. I hope that is the case. It is yet to be seen in some areas of Australia. No matter what I say here, it will not mean anything. Presumably it is not going to mean anything in future for some of the people who made certain comments today. For example, the mover of this motion, Senator Kernot, asked whether I had made deals with the government. She said she did not know for certain whether I had, but that it was likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not.

—She said, `It is likely, but I have no knowledge of this. My attitude in principle is that once you put your vote up for sale, you can possibly be bought on everything.' Senator Kernot then pontificated on a number of other areas. It was not only her. Another Democrat made a similar statement, which I am very surprised about. I am very surprised that you should imply that there is some sort of deal being done between the government and me over Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: I also noted the statements made by ex-senator Evans, now the shadow Treasurer, about this matter. If he thinks his arguments and the government's arguments on the budget have no effect on me, that is their problem, is it not? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is not about the principle of trading across issues. This motion is about whether we should privatise one-third of Telstra. Senator Alston's arguments, to me, seem to be summed up as these: we should privatise Telstra because the economic cheer squad says we should; we should privatise Telstra because everybody else is doing it; and, we should privatise Telstra because there is no role for government in a strategic industry like telecommunications. I ask Senator Alston: who is this economic cheer squad? They mostly speak for business—let's be frank about this—and some of them have a vested interest in the outcome because of their companies' links with Telstra and future pay television scenarios.

SPEECH.PARA: On the idea that we should do it because everybody else is doing it, the fact that lemming-like we must do what everybody else is fashionably doing these days—even Cuba and Albania: what about Cuba and Albania? Do we want to emulate their health care systems, for example, Senator Alston or do we just pick off telecommunications in this instance? Privatisation is economic fashion. It does not take account of Australia's demography, geography and history on this matter.

On the matter of ideology, the ideology that I think underpins the privatisation debate of the coalition government is that, first, the private sector always, no matter what, does everything better. I invite you to look at the recent example of the private sector running of the Olympic Games and the fact that the Sydney Olympic Organising Committee says, `Never again; it didn't work properly.' It is kind of like the Animal Farm argument: four legs good; two legs bad. This is ideological obsession. The second argument is that the private sector has a greater right to profits and the third ideological argument is that the public sector under no circumstances can be efficient and profitable. This motion seeks to demonstrate otherwise. There is a role for government in strategic industries.

I am asking the Senate to vote for this motion today in order to tell the government to think again; to put Australia's interests first; to congratulate a publicly owned company which is both efficient and profitable and which is doing well on behalf of all the Australians who currently own it. I want to ask this government to stop trying to flog off any of it to any other domestic or foreign owners. I ask all senators to acknowledge that the only argument left is that of blind ideology. They should remember that, on 2 March, 56 per cent of Australians voted for those parties which are opposed to the partial privatisation of Telstra. This government should not claim false mandates.

I have commented on his position as an educator. In fact, he has had the distinguished positions of president of the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and chancellor of two universities—Deakin University and the Northern Territory University. He has made contributions in law and education and in far too many community service groups to properly name and do credit to.

In the last few years, in his position as Administrator of the Northern Territory, I can only say that he has done the Northern Territory proud. He has been an administrator who has moved around the entire Northern Territory constantly, hosted hundreds of functions in various capacities, particularly at Government House in Darwin, and who has acted as an emissary for the Northern Territory in other states of Australia, particularly in a number of official visits to Indonesian provinces. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to rise to speak in the adjournment debate to pay tribute to a great Australian who recently passed away, Mr Dunc Gray, who won the gold medal for Australia in cycling in the 1932 Olympic Games. He came from Goulburn, close to this place, and represented Australia at three Olympic Games—1928, 1932 and 1936. In 1936—in some senses, the infamous Olympic Games at Berlin—he was given the honour of leading the Australian team into the arena and carrying the flag.

SPEECH.PARA: Dunc Gray, in recent years, got considerable publicity—and quite rightly so—for being Australia's oldest living gold medal winner. I do not have the actual figures, but I would think there are probably no more than about 50 Australians, in 100 years of Olympic Games, who have won gold medals—and Dunc Gray was one of them. At the Olympics in Los Angeles in 1932, I think he was one of only two gold medal winners for Australia. I may not have that absolutely correct, but we certainly did not win as many gold medals as we recently won in Atlanta.

Dunc Gray, whom I never had the honour to meet, but I did see him on a number of occasions in recent years on television programs and in newspaper articles, struck me as the quintessential Australian sportsperson. Looking at photographs of him as a cyclist in the late 1920s and early 1930s, he was certainly a very handsome and fit young man—the sort of image I think most of us who were not ever able to be as athletic as he was aspired to in the way we looked and conducted ourselves in an athletic way.

I also note that in recent times, despite being in his very late 80s, he was always quick and sharp with his comments and still had a great interest in a range of issues. I think he clearly was a great Australian.

I was taken by some remarks he made just over two years ago when at a function to promote the Olympic Games. He was at a function with the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Before Mr Keating was able to say anything, Dunc Gray expressed a few views that some might find controversial, but I was struck by them. He insisted on expressing these views to everybody at this function—at which several hundred were present—as the oldest Olympic gold medallist. He said:
If we want to be Australians, we must have our own flag.
Dunc said that as he reached into his inside pocket and handed out a sketch of his favourite design to Mr Keating. He went on to say:
When I won the gold medal at the 1932 Olympics in Los Angeles, they put the Australian flag up to the masthead and you could only see the Union Jack.
Then they played God Save the King and I wondered who was I riding for.
In a later interview on Channel 9 he said:

They presented the medals, they hoisted the flag to the mast and so on. Then they played God Save the King and they had a great big Union Jack on the Australian flag and I thought, `Oh my God,' as I was walking across, `who do I ride for, England or Australia?'
It is somewhat ironic that four years later he still carried the flag which he made those comments about into the Olympic Games in Berlin.

I want to pay tribute to Dunc Gray for having the courage to express what some people would say would be controversial views. I also think it ought to be noted that as a gold medal winner he is in a very strong position to make a comment which I do not think many of us could in any way disparage even if we disagree with it.

He has won a gold medal. He has stood on the podium as the flag has been put up on the mast in front of thousands of people at the velodrome in Los Angeles. He has heard God save the King being played, but now that has been changed. Of course, he has marched, holding that flag, into the Berlin Olympic Games.

So I do not take his remarks as being in any way critical of, or disloyal to, Australia but as indicating that at the age of 87 he was able to show that he had moved on and still could remember some of what he considered the incongruity of having a symbol that to him was not quite clearly Australian.

I think that is the real point. Dunc Gray was a quintessential Australian who, even in the 1930s, long before it became a matter of even public controversy, was willing to consider that maybe this country did need to have its own national anthem, which we now have, and ultimately our distinctive flag that is clearly and unambiguously Australian. Irrespective of those controversial remarks, I want to pay tribute to a very great Australian who has done great honour to this country and has been a representative of whom we can all be proud.
